awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T1: Increasing regional to global-scale resilience in Food-Energy-Water systems through coordinated management,technology and institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Concerns over food, energy and water (FEW) security and an enhanced ability to withstand future disturbances and shocks (i.e., resilience) require careful management of these coupled resources. This project is centered on the Columbia River Basin (CRB) comprising portions of seven states in the U.S. Pacific Northwest and a portion of Canada.  The project will develop a resilience assessment facing the FEW systems as a result of rapid changes in land use and human populations, climate variability, and the complex interactions between physical, biological, and human systems. This understanding can then be used to assess the governance and policy challenges associated with the CRB from both national and international perspectives.  Engagement with stakeholders throughout the project will provide information on which management strategies are feasible within existing political and socio-cultural institutions, and what aspects of institutions might be relaxed or reformed to enable innovations and greater resilience.

Understanding interdependencies within the Food-Energy-Water (FEW) system is critical to maintain FEW security. Strategies are needed to increase the overall resilience of FEW systems across multiple spatial and temporal scales. This project examines the hypothesis that coordinated management of physical (e.g., reservoirs, aquifers, and batteries) and non-physical (e.g., water markets, social capital, and insurance markets) storage systems across the three sectors promotes resilience. The overarching goal is to examine effective strategies to mutually balance benefits and increase resilience across integrated FEW systems. The project will develop a transferable framework for FEW systems involving 1) a theoretical foundation characterizing the region's FEW system that is generalizable to national and global scales, 2) integration of state-of-the-science computational models to capture FEW system interactions, 3) identification of ancillary benefits or unintended consequences using the modeling platforms, and 4) utilization of a two-way stakeholder engagement to develop new strategies and remove barriers to adoption of new coordinated practices.

por.por_cntn:
Together, rapid population growth, economic development, and associated climate change have placed increased stresses on our natural resources. Concerns over food, energy and water (FEW) security and the need to be able to withstand these pressures requires careful management of these resources. Our region of focus was on the Columbia River Basin (CRB), an ideal location to explore FEW interactions due to its management complexity and that it is becoming increasingly ?storage limited? as climate change causes precipitation to more frequently as rain and less frequently as snow, thereby decreasing seasonal water storage in the snowpack. We hypothesized that innovative ways to manage water storage will help to alleviate these concerns. We further hypothesized that innovations in human institutions and/or new technological advances can also help. We developed a tightly-integrated, interdisciplinary approach that involves researcher expertise spanning a continuum from conceptual to concrete.

We created a conceptual map of the FEW nexus as it exists in the Columbia River basin; this map became the starting point for all following modeling activities, spanning from theoretical frameworks to system dynamics (stock and full) models, to highly mechanistic modeling frameworks. We developed a theoretical foundation to characterize our region?s FEW system, which can be generalizable to national and global scales. Moving closer to concrete, we integrated state-of-the-science computational models to capture FEW system tradeoffs under a variety of climate and land use scenarios. We used this framework to characterize how human decision may either exacerbate or alleviate some of these stresses. We also evaluated a few possible institutional and technological solutions to our regional FEW problems. These included managed aquifer recovery (MAR), wherein surplus water during the winter season of low water use is used to recharge groundwater aquifers, to be used during the summer of high water use. MAR was found to be a viable strategy for managing our water supplies, particularly in the face of increasing drought frequency and severity. We also examined the use of HighTech greenhouses as a possible path towards sustainable intensification of food production systems. We found that, while vegetable crop yield can be as much as six times higher than a field crop with less water use, energy use is greatly increased. Further research is needed to increase energy efficiency. We also examined the use of climate-adapted crop varieties (those that develop more slowly in a warmer climate) and discovered that yields are greater but at the cost of higher year-to-year variability in yield. This increase in variability can contribute to economic uncertainty and may result in higher crop insurance costs that may outweigh the increased revenue from higher yields. Numerous other strategies (e.g., irrigation technology, pumped storage hydropower, floodplain storage) were explored.

We brought in a stakeholder advisory group (SAG) to discuss project goals (early in the project), determine next steps (throughout the project), and discuss project outcomes (end of the project). This provided information as to which management strategies are feasible within the confines of existing political and socio-cultural institutions, and what aspects of institutions might be relaxed or reformed to enable innovations. The SAG also helped us in developing the metrics that would were used to quantify the sustainability and resilience of the FEW system under a variety of institutional and technological innovations that we explored. We called this system of metrics the Sustainability and Resilience Calculator. These metrics spanned across the three pillars of sustainability: environmental health, economic viability, and social equity for each of the food, energy, and water sectors. Many of these metrics were characterized across the entire region; for example, one PhD student focused his dissertation on incorporating social science dynamics into quantification of FEW resilience. Legal dimensions were also analyzed and described. We also trained numerous postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students, including a summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program. In summary, products include computational modeling platforms that can be transferred to any region of interest to characterize the pressures on our FEW systems (specifically in regions with diverse irrigated agriculture, a reliance on hydropower generation, and extensive management for aquatic endangered species) and to quantify the effectiveness of possible strategies to alleviate these stressors. This information can be (and, in some cases is being) used to formulate policy that would incentivize development or use of such technologies.
